page.title: 08THE BATTLE OF JERSEY
page.content: On 6 January 1781, a French army led by Baron de Rullecourt embarked to invade and conquer the most southerly of the Channel Islands. The battle which followed represents the last of many attempts by the French to take the island of Jersey, and is the last time the French fought on British soil. The French landed in darkness on both sides of La Platte Rocque and made their way across country towards St. Helier where the battle ensued. The area where the French came ashore at La Platte Rocque is marked by a commemorative plaque. At that point the seashore is flat and rocky and at low tide the sea almost disappears from view.
